official-title.#text: To establish a renewable electricity standard, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico

text.#text: In this section:

term.#tail: means the total quantity of electric energy sold by a retail electric supplier, expressed in terms of kilowatt hours, to electric customers for purposes other than resale during the most recent calendar year for which information is available.

electric energy that is not incremental hydropower generated by a hydroelectric facility; and

term.#tail: means electric energy generated by a renewable energy resource.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means solar, wind, ocean, tidal, geothermal energy, biomass, landfill gas, incremental hydropower, or hydrokinetic energy.

text.#text: The term
The term

the additional generation from a modification that is placed in service on or after the date of enactment of this section, to expand electricity production at a facility used to generate electric energy from a renewable energy resource;

the additional generation above the average generation during the 3-year period ending on the date of enactment of this section at a facility used to generate electric energy from a renewable energy resource or to cofire biomass that was placed in service before the date of enactment of this section; or

the portion of the electric generation from a facility placed in service on or after the date of enactment of this section, or a modification to a facility placed in service before the date of enactment of this section made on or after January 1, 2001, associated with cofiring biomass.

term.#tail: means a person that sells electric energy to electric consumers that sold not less than 1,000,000 megawatt hours of electric energy to electric consumers for purposes other than resale during the preceding calendar year.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: includes a person that sells electric energy to electric consumers that, in combination with the sales of any affiliate organized after the date of enactment of this section, sells not less than 1,000,000 megawatt hours of electric energy to consumers for purposes other than resale.

text.#text: The term
For purposes of this paragraph, sales by any person to a parent company or to other affiliates of the person shall not be treated as sales to electric consumers.

header.#text: Issuance of Federal renewable energy credits

to verify and issue Federal renewable energy credits to generators of renewable energy;
to track the sale, exchange, and retirement of the credits; and
to enforce the requirements of this section.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall issue to a generator of electric energy 1 Federal renewable energy credit for each kilowatt hour of electric energy generated by the use of a renewable energy resource at an eligible facility.

text.#text: Except as otherwise provided in this paragraph, the

For purpose of compliance with this section, Federal renewable energy credits for incremental hydropower shall be based on the increase in average annual generation resulting from the efficiency improvements or capacity additions.
used to determine a historic average annual generation baseline for the hydroelectric facility; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: or the

text.#text: certified by the
The incremental generation shall be calculated using the same water flow information that is—

The calculation of the Federal renewable energy credits for incremental hydropower shall not be based on any operational changes at the hydroelectric facility that is not directly associated with the efficiency improvements or capacity additions.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall issue 2 renewable energy credits for each kilowatt hour of electric energy generated and supplied to the grid in a calendar year through the use of a renewable energy resource at an eligible facility located on Indian land.

text.#text: The
For purposes of this paragraph, renewable energy generated by biomass cofired with other fuels is eligible for 2 credits only if the biomass was grown on the land.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall issue 3 renewable energy credits to the customer for each kilowatt hour generated.

text.#text: In the case of electric energy generated by a renewable energy resource at an on-site eligible facility that is not larger than 1 megawatt in capacity and is used to offset all or part of the requirements of a customer for electric energy, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall issue not more than 3 credits per kilowatt hour.

text.#text: In the case of an on-site eligible facility on Indian land, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall issue the Federal renewable energy credits based on the proportion of the renewable energy resources used.

text.#text: If both a renewable energy resource and a nonrenewable energy resource are used to generate the electric energy, the

header.#text: Combination of renewable and nonrenewable energy resources

Incremental hydropower shall be subject to all applicable environmental laws and licensing and regulatory requirements.
Nothing in this section diminishes any authority of a State or political subdivision of a State—
to adopt or enforce any law (including regulations) respecting renewable energy, including programs that exceed the required quantity of renewable energy under this section; or
to regulate the acquisition and disposition of Federal renewable energy credits by retail electric suppliers.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall relieve any person of any requirement otherwise applicable under this section.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978/s:610/ss:k/p:1/sp:A

text.#text: No law or regulation referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in consultation with States that have in effect renewable energy programs, shall—

text.#text: The
preserve the integrity of the State programs, including programs that exceed the required quantity of renewable energy under this section; and
facilitate coordination between the Federal program and State programs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall incorporate common elements of existing renewable energy programs, including State programs, to ensure administrative ease, market transparency and effective enforcement.

text.#text: In the regulations establishing the program under this section, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall work with the States to minimize administrative burdens and costs to retail electric suppliers.

text.#text: In carrying out this section, the

header.#text: Minimization of administrative burdens and costs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978/s:610/ss:b

text.#text: An electric utility that has sales of electric energy that are subject to rate regulation (including any utility with rates that are regulated by the Commission and any State regulated electric utility) shall not be denied the opportunity to recover the full amount of the prudently incurred incremental cost of renewable energy obtained to comply with the requirements of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Sciences under which the Academy shall conduct a comprehensive evaluation of all aspects of the program established under this section.

text.#text: The
The study shall include an evaluation of—
the effectiveness of the program in increasing the market penetration and lowering the cost of the eligible renewable energy technologies;
the opportunities for any additional technologies and sources of renewable energy emerging since the date of enactment of this section;
the impact on the regional diversity and reliability of supply sources, including the power quality benefits of distributed generation;
the regional resource development relative to renewable potential and reasons for any investment in renewable resources; and
the net cost/benefit of the renewable electricity standard to the national and State economies, including—
retail power costs;
the economic development benefits of investment;
avoided costs related to environmental and congestion mitigation investments that would otherwise have been required;
the impact on natural gas demand and price; and
the effectiveness of green marketing programs at reducing the cost of renewable resources.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall transmit to
a report describing the results of the evaluation and any recommendations for modifications and improvements to the program.

text.#text: The

At least 75 percent of the funds provided to each State for each fiscal year shall be used to promote renewable energy production through grants, production incentives, or other State-approved funding mechanisms.
The funds shall be allocated to the States on the basis of retail electric sales subject to the renewable electricity standard under this section or through voluntary participation.
